Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive follow-up care via a mobile app or at an in-person visit during the first 30 days after the operation.

Participants.evidence: among ambulatory patients undergoing breast reconstruction at an academic ambulatory care hospital.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive follow-up care via a mobile app or at an in-person visit during the first 30 days after the operation.

Objective.evidence: Objective: To determine whether follow-up care delivered via a mobile app can be used to avert in-person follow-up care visits compared with conventional, in-person follow-up care in the first 30 days following ambulatory surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary end point was the number of in-person follow-up visits during the first 30 days after the operation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive follow-up care via a mobile app or at an in-person visit during the first 30 days after the operation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of the 65 women in the study (mean [SD] age, 47.7 [13.4] years), 32 (49%) were in the mobile app group, and 33 (51%) were in the in-person follow-up care group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Those in the mobile app group attended a mean of 0.66 in-person visits, vs 1.64 in-person visits in the in-person follow-up care group, for a difference of 0.40 times fewer in-person visits (95% CI, 0.24-0.66; P <â€‰.001)

Harms.evidence: There was no difference between groups in the number of telephone communications, satisfaction scores, or complication rates.
